intro: Cerinthe strigosa, commonly known as the woolly cerinthe, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and western Asia. It belongs to the family Scrophulariaceae and is characterized by its hairy, glandular leaves and spikes of tubular, two-lipped flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in full sun to partial shade. Its flowers, which range in color from purple to pink, attract various pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Cerinthe strigosa is often cultivated in gardens for its ornamental value and ecological benefits.
